text:
Jim’s Disk Management pic of his Win10 device is quite interesting. 
- Only two partitions listed 
Reagentc /info will(as you’ve suggested) show if it is really present. 
There are a few possibilities why not shown in Disk Management(which usually
does show the Recovery partition but without a label(only a Disk # and 
partition # are shown in Disk Management). 
Some possibilities 
1. device was cloned from an image with only the System and Windows partitions 
2. device was restored from an image with only the System and Windows partitions 
3. Recovery partition(and possibly an additional OEM
factor-reset-everything-to-as-ship-conditon partition) was deleted expanding the
C: drive 
4. Similar to #3(deleting Recovery partition) since a USB Recovery disk was
created making the Recovery partition redundant if the created recovery disk was
the preferred Recovery method(this might also have occurred at the time the
device was a Win7 device) 
5. Disk is MBR and a combination of one of the above 
There are few other reasons why the Recovery partitions is not shown…some of
which requires a a bit of effort to hide that partition from Disk Management. 
There is another way to determine if a Recovery partition is present on that
device. 
Settings/System/Recovery/Advanced Startup 
- Once restarted if a Recovery partition is present the device normally shows 4
option(Continue -Exit to Windows, Turn Off-PC, Use a device, Troubleshoot). If
the Recovery partition is not present, only two options are normally
shown(Start-up Settings and option to load the BIOS(MBR) or UEFI Firmware
Settings. 
We may never know, since Jim’s message was intended to be sent elsewhere(nor did
it include the Disk Management’s Top View(Volume List) but that pic(showing
Disk Management’s Graphical View does seem to indicate something abnormal
occurred before that pic was taken. 
…w

From: 'Susan Bradley' via PatchManagement <patchmanagement@googlegroups.com>
Sent: January 17, 2024 4:21 PM
To: patchmanagement@googlegroups.com; JBoettger@mcandrews-ip.com
Subject: Re: [patchmanagement] Feedback to Microsoft 
I'm guessing you meant to send this to someone else? 
I'll recap: 
Feel free to recap/copy and paste. 
Windows 10 has a separate patch KB5034441, Windows 11's version is included in
the Windows 11 cumulative update. 
It is attempting to patch the Windows recovery partition for a vulnerability
whereby an attacker can boot under the OS and gain access to the bitlocker
protected hard drive.  The problem is OLDER Windows 10 typically have a small
recovery partition and it's to the left of the c drive making it REALLY hard to
expand it and give it more room.  Newer Windows 10 installs put the recovery
partition to the right where you can easily expand the partition. 
With this update you need at least 250MB free space. 
Going forward you probably want to allow for a 1 gig recovery partition to leave
you room. 
Problem is you can't see how free your partition is, nor WHICH recovery
partition is in use without using a Powershell command  reagentc /info and then
a tool like minitool partition wizard to see the actual free space. On your
Windows 11 I'll bet BOTH recovery partitions are not in use. 
[cid:image004.png@01DA49AF.FC1ACC10] 
My actual recovery partition in use is number 4 
[cid:image005.png@01DA49AF.FC1ACC10] 
So step one - which partition - if any - is in use?  reagentc /info is your
friend 
Step two use minitool partition wizard free to see how REALLY free that
partition is and what are your options for resizing
Link: https://groups.google.com/d/msgid/patchmanagement/DS0PR10MB7341A8A37EE5C80A1A4023629E712%40DS0PR10MB7341.namprd10.prod.outlook.com
